title: 108_hr4434
content: The Act may be cited as the "No Child Left Behind Reform Act" and includes provisions for Adequate Yearly Progress. The "No Child Left Behind Reform Act" includes amendments to the definition of Adequate Yearly Progress, focusing on academic assessments and growth measures. Amendment to Section 1116(a)(1)(B) of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 removes certain language related to academic assessment and school improvement. SEC. 1120C. GRANTS FOR INCREASING DATA CAPACITY FOR PURPOSES OF AYP. The Secretary may award grants to State educational agencies to develop data systems for accountability and subgrants to local agencies for managing information databases. Priority is given to agencies with growth models or proficiency indexes. States must use funds for capacity building. The Secretary awards grants to State educational agencies to develop data systems for accountability and subgrants to local agencies for managing information databases. Local educational agencies receiving subgrants must use funds to upgrade databases or create unique student identifiers for measuring adequate yearly progress by purchasing software or hardware, hiring staff, and providing training. The State educational agency must submit an application to the Secretary for a grant under this section, while local educational agencies must submit an application to the State educational agency for a subgrant. The applications should demonstrate the ability to implement a database and use data effectively to improve student achievement. Authorization of Appropriations: $80,000,000 authorized for fiscal years 2005, 2006, and 2007. SEC. 4. TARGETING TRANSFER OPTIONS AND SUPPLEMENTAL SERVICES. Targeting Transfer Options and Supplemental Services in the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to include provisions for students failing to make adequate yearly progress and those eligible for services under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act. The Education Act is amended to ensure students failing to make adequate yearly progress or eligible for services under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act are placed in the least restrictive environment appropriate. The Education Act is amended to allow students transferring to another public school to continue enrollment, effective when the appropriated amount for title I of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act is less than the authorized amount for the fiscal year. SEC. 5. DEFINITION OF HIGHLY QUALIFIED TEACHERS. Section 9101(23)(B)(ii) of the Elementary and Secondary Act of 1965 is amended to include requirements for middle school teachers to pass a State-approved middle school generalist exam and obtain a State social studies certificate to teach history and geography. Teachers in middle or secondary schools must obtain a State certificate to teach various subjects such as history, geography, economics, civics, earth science, biology, chemistry, and physics.
